                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_0","title":"Mental Health and Websites 3/24/2020","content":"Attached to this email is the 2nd edition of the ORCSD Mental Health and Wellness Newsletter.  This resource is provided to all district families by the ORCSD K-12 Counseling Department.
\n
\nMental Health and Wellness Newsletter","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_1","title":"Update #14 3/20/2020","content":"
Dear Parents, Faculty, Students and Community Members, 
\n
\n\n
In our continued effort to keep the community informed during these challenging times we offer the following information provided to us from NH Department of Health and Human Services (NH DHHS).  We have continued to work closely with state officials since learning a middle school staff member tested positive for COVID-19.  The information below comes from communication direct from state health officials at NH DHHS.  
\n
\n\n
As a result of the positive test, NH DHHS requested for the ORCSD Administration to provide contact information for anyone who was identified as having had close contact with the individual.  NH DHHS defines close contact as having been within 6 feet of the individual for longer than 10 minutes. Nurses from NH DHHS are in the process of contacting all of those individuals or their parent/guardian and will instruct them how to self-quarantine. A guide for self-quarantine can be found at: https://www.nh.gov/covid19/residents/documents/self-quarantine-covid.pdf 
\n
\n\n
NH DHHS is conducting a public health investigation related to this situation. It is possible the middle school campus has experienced unknown exposure to the coronavirus, COVID-19.  For this reason, everyone on campus should self-observe.  If you are experiencing symptoms such as a fever, respiratory illness, aches or fatigue, please stay home and away from others and contact a healthcare provider. A guide for self-observation can be found at: https://www.nh.gov/covid19/residents/documents/self-observation-covid.pdf 
\n
\n\n
The new coronavirus, COVID19, continues to spread across our country, indicating that people need to follow recommendations to protect their health.  
\n
\n\n
If you are not contacted by NH DHHS, but are a member of our school staff, experience symptoms and are over the age of 60 years old and/or have chronic medical problems, regardless of age, please self-isolate and contact your healthcare provider. 
\n
\n\n
If you are not contacted by NH DHHS and experience mild symptoms, please self-isolate and stay home until:  \n\n    
At least 7 days have passed since symptoms first appeared \n    
At least 3 days (72 hours) have passed since recovery; which is defined as resolution of fever without the use of fever-reducing medications and improvement in respiratory symptoms \n\n
The safety of our students, faculty, employees and visitors is our top priority. To ensure your health and safety, we have been following CDC guidelines cleaning for our high-traffic areas and frequently touched surfaces. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019ncov/community/organizations/cleaning-disinfection.html 
\n
\n\n
To prevent further spread of the disease in our community, please do the following: \n\n    
Wash hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use alcohol-based hand sanitizers. \n    
Avoid touching eyes, mouth and nose with unwashed hands. \n    
Do not to share personal items such as water bottles, smokes and/or vapes. \n    
Avoid close contact with individuals who are sick. \n    
Stay home when you are sick. Remain home for at least 24 hours after you no longer have a fever (without fever-reducing medication) or signs of a fever (i.e., chills, feeling warm, flushed appearance), and respiratory symptoms are improving. \n    
Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then immediately discard the tissue in the trash. \n    
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces. \n\n
To learn more about COVID-19 please visit the following website: 
\n
\n\n
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) 
\n
\n\n
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/summary.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fsummary.html
\n
\n\n
NH Department of Health and Human Services (NH DHHS)
\n
\n\n
https://www.nh.gov/covid19/
\n
\n\n
The health and safety of our students, staff and community remain our top priority.  As more information becomes available, we will share all that we can. 
\n
\n\n
Sincerely, 
\n
\n\n
Dr. Jim Morse, ORCSD Superintendent \n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_2","title":"Update #13 3/19/2020","content":"
Dear Parents, Guardians, Faculty, Staff and Community members,
\n
\n\n
\n
I hope that this email finds you well.  We are concerned about all of our students and staff at this time.  Over the last 24 hours I have heard from many families about the challenges being faced as a result of the positive test of a middle school staff member for COVID 19 .  Please know that the health and safety of our students, staff and families is our highest priority. Throughout the epidemic we have aimed to be as transparent as possible as we share necessary information and provide support families.  \n
 \n
Yesterday we notified the community that a staff member at Oyster River Middle School had tested positive for COVID 19.  As we noted in our email yesterday, as soon as we were made aware of the positive COVID 19 test, district leadership reached out to the NH Division of Public Health and the Department of Education who are advising us on this situation.  DHHS told us that all staff and students who had close contact with the staff member in question will receive a phone call from the Bureau of Infectious Disease Control at the NH Division of Public Health today to provide guidance and support for how to proceed. Unfortunately, we do not know how long this will take but if we learn otherwise, we will update our guidance to you.
\n
\n\n
\n
Should you or family experience any of the symptoms as listed below, please contact your health care provider.
\n
\n\n
\n
SYMPTOMS SUCH AS:\n\n    
dry cough (no sputum production)\n    
shortness of breath\n    
chest tightness\n    
fever\n    
fatigue\n\n
\n
We will continue to keep you abreast with the information we can share as we learn it.
\n
\n\n
\n
Sincerely,
\n
\n\n
\n
Dr. Jim Morse\n
ORCSD Superintendent\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_3","title":"Update #12 3/18/2020","content":"
Dear Members of the Oyster River Community,\n
 \n
I have received requests for the name of the middle school staff member who has tested positive for COVID-19.  Please understand that the school district is prohibited from releasing the identity of the staff member, which is protected information.  In my prior email, I attached advice issued by the CDC as guidance for the middle school faculty, staff and families for monitoring their or their children’s health. 
\n
\n\n
\n
Should you or family experience any of the symptoms as listed below, please contact your health care provider.
\n
\n\n
\n
SYMPTOMS SUCH AS:\n\n    
dry cough (no sputum production)\n    
shortness of breath (unable to hold your breath for 10 seconds)\n    
chest tightness\n    
fever\n    
fatigue\n\n
The School District is working closely with the NH Division of Public Health to reduce the risk of harm to members of the school community. The NH Division of Public Health Services is charged with assessing and responding to public health risks.  That agency will be contacting faculty, staff and families as they deem necessary in light of the circumstances.
\n
\n\n
\n
Thank you for understanding the limitations upon which the School District must operate.
\n
\n\n
\n
Sincerely,
\n
\n\n
\n
Dr. Jim Morse\n
Superintendent\n
 \n
Resources:\n
\n
This document is to be used by those that have a CONFIRMED positive test per CDC recommendations.
\n
\n\n
\n
This document is to be used to assist those that are actively MONITORING for symptoms at home per CDC recommendations:\n
\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_4","title":"Update #11 3/18/2020","content":"
Dear Parents, Guardians and Staff,
\n
\n\n
\n
We are writing to inform you a middle school staff member has tested positive for COVID-19 and communicated this with us today.  We have contacted the NH Division of Public Health as well as the Department of Education.  We are awaiting further guidance from the NH Division of Public Health.  Once we receive the additional guidance, we will share this with the Oyster River Community.  This is all of the information we can provide at this time, as medical information is protected.
\n
\n\n
\n
Please see attached guidance from the CDC. 
\n
\n\n
\n
Sincerely,\n
\n
Dr. Jim Morse
\n
\n\n
This document is to be used by those that have a CONFIRMED positive test per CDC recommendations.
\n
\nThis document is to be used to assist those that are actively MONITORING for symptoms at home per CDC recommendations.
\n
\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_5","title":"Update #10 3/17/2020","content":"
Dear Parents & Guardians
\n
\n\n
This update is to give you all a sense of where we are on a host of issues. 
\n
\n\n
Remote Learning: Our teachers and paraeducators are working diligently to prepare materials for your child’s continued education. Remote Learning has never been done before in PK-12 schools in New Hampshire.  Predictably, there will be many kinks.  We will have a soft roll-out Thursday and Friday and a total implementation next Monday.  We will use technology as appropriate and GO LEARN bags when technology is not appropriate.  Parents will receive an email from their child’s building principal within the next 24 hours with specific details for how this will work at a given age level.
\n
\n\n
Support for remote learning: As I said above teachers and paraeducators have been working diligently to prepare for remote learning.  Since this is the first time ORCSD has implemented remote learning, there will be hiccups.  If you have issues accessing Schoology or a particular assignment, please email the teacher first.  If it is a technology issue they will direct it to the right person.  Feel free to contact the building principal with any concerns.
\n
\n\n
Food:  The district is delivering over 500 meals today.  You can have breakfast and lunch delivered to your home for your Oyster River Students.  This service is free, the food is being prepared by our cooks with pride and being delivered by our drivers with enthusiasm.  If you would like to have food delivered to your home for your child, watch for the next survey to parents from the ORCSD Child Nutrition Department.
\n
\n\n
Special Education Services & Section 504:  Our special education faculty and staff have been working on different models in order to continue with special education and related services.  Each case manager will be reaching out to parents in order to create a communication plan and discuss how the services will be implemented through remote learning.  Some services may be provided virtually either through a direct approach with the student or through a consultative approach with the student and/or parent.  You may also receive activities through Schoology or through the GO LEARN bags.  The special education faculty and staff will be available to assist you with implementation.  We are working hard to continue to provide your students with their services and very much appreciate your partnership.  Once school is back in session, services and progress towards goals will be reviewed with parents to determine next steps.  Please note no services will occur in homes or in the school setting.  We cannot ensure social distancing and care deeply for the health and well-being of our students, faculty, and staff.  The school district will continue to hold necessary meetings virtually, using Microsoft Teams, but can accommodate another virtual option.  Case managers and Assistant Directors will communicate more about meeting specifics.  We will continue to monitor and address concerns and encourage parents to have regular communication with their child’s special education case manager or their child’s 504 case manager.
\n
\n\n
Access to school buildings during the closure:  Our custodians are in the process of deep cleaning all buildings in the district which will result in restricted access for all staff and community members while school is closed.  
\n
\n\n
Middle and High School families may have need to gather student instruments or other necessary items left at school.  Hours for this will be communicated by building principals over the next few days.  
\n
\n\n
Moharimet and Mast Way will provide time to pick up needed materials on Thursday.  
\n
\n\n
Your child’s school principal will be sending out additional information within the next 24 hours with specific instructions to collect necessary student belongings.  Keep in mind that CDC guidance tells us to prevent gatherings of people in order to stop the spread of COVID-19.  If you do not need to access the building, please stay away per CDC guidance until we reopen.
\n
\n\n
Social Distancing:  The latest from the CDC is there should be no more than 10 people in a gathering and that you should be six feet away from each other.  This is far harder than it seems as we are very social by nature, especially teenagers!  Attached to this email is a quick reference guide for what social distancing is and how best to protect yourself and others.
\n
\n\n
Administration Contacts:  Below are the contacts for the SAU Administration.  Each Principal will also provide building specific contacts.  Be on the lookout for email communications from your child’s principal later today and from your child’s teachers over the coming days.
\n
\n\n
As always, please continue to directly communicate with your child’s teacher or case manager for classroom-related questions and feel free to reach out to an administrator for questions beyond the classroom.
\n
\n\n
            Dr. James Morse, Superintendent                                 jmorse@orcsd.org\n
            Todd Allen, Assistant Superintendent                            tallen@orcsd.org\n
            Catherine Plourde, Director of Student Services             cplourde@orcsd.org\n
           \n
Be well,
\n
\n\n
Dr. Jim Morse\n
ORCSD Superintendent
\n
\nSocial Distancing Document
\n
\nCoronavirus Guidance\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_6","title":"Update #9 3/16/2020","content":"Please see the attached newsletter from The ORCSD K-12 Counseling Department to provide support and guidance around the Coronavirus.
\n
\nMental Wellness Newsletter","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_7","title":"School Lunch During Closure","content":"
School Meal Order Form\n
Oyster River Schools will be delivering breakfast and lunch for your children at no cost to you during the school closure due to COVID 19.  \n
Please submit a form for each child in your household who will require meals.  All forms must be submitted by 9:00 am on Tuesday, March 17th.  A new form request will be sent out on Thursday afternoon for next week’s meals. \n
Online Meal Order Form\n
If you have questions, contact Doris Demers at ddemers@orcsd.org.\n
Breakfast will consist of grains, fruit or juice and milk.                                           \n
Lunch will consist of protein, grains, fruit, vegetables and milk.\n
Required: Someone must be at your location to receive meals when they are delivered between the hours of 11 am and 1 pm.  Meals for 2 days will be delivered Tues & Thurs. for week 1, then M, W, F moving forward.\n
Doris Demers, DTR, SNS                                                                                               \n
Director","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_8","title":"Update #8 3/15/2020 NH DOE Guidance","content":"This document was sent to district leaders across the state from the New Hampshire Department of Education.
\n
\nNH DOE Guidance Document","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_9","title":"Update #7 3/15/2020","content":"
Dear Parents & Guardians,
\n
\n\n
The Oyster River Cooperative School District will close on Tuesday, March 17, 2020.  At this time, we plan on returning April 6, 2020.  This parallels the time UNH will be out. 
\n
\n\n
There is the possibility that this closure may be extended.  We will keep you informed.  We will be reviewing guidance from the NH Department of Health & Human Services, the NH Department of Education, and the CDC, and making decisions that are best for our school district.  
\n
\n\n
We will be moving to a remote learning model for education.  The model will be much different than you see at a college or university level.  Why?  We have primary age children learning to read and compute.  We have children with disabilities that require a different type of remote learning.  We have upper elementary and middle school age children that are growing in their intellectual capacity, and of course we have high school age children who are far more capable of abstract thinking and more sophisticated programming.  Your teachers will be working tomorrow to build a framework for remote learning designed for your children at their level.  We will give them through Wednesday to build content that can be delivered remotely.  I will send a follow-up memo on Remote Learning Tuesday.
\n
\n\n
In over four decades of service to children, I have never had to close school for a prolonged period of time.  Why now?  The CDC is recommending six feet distance between people (social distancing).  Schools are densely populated, so it is impossible to create the distance recommended by the CDC since COVID-19/the Coronavirus spreads through person to person contact and is highly transmissible.  In addition, the CDC recommends you self-quarantine.   You and your family, should, as much as humanly possible, stay at home, wash your hands frequently, and follow other recommendations by our CDC.  Our school nurses sent out an email on Friday including a very detailed letter and attached several resources for you and your family.  This letter can be found on our website with all of our communication to date.
\n    \n
We are in unprecedented times. We care greatly for you and your children and want you to be safe.  We will continue to communicate throughout the closure.
\n
\n\n
Sincerely,
\n
\n\n
Dr. Jim Morse\n
Superintendent, Oyster River \n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_10","title":"Update #6 3/13/2020","content":"To Parents and Guardians,
\n
\nIn this challenging time as we sort out appropriate measures to help mitigate the transmission of the coronavirus, COVID-19, we appreciate your calls and emails of concern regarding your children.  Between Dr. Morse and our SAU, individual school administration, and our nursing department and staff, the Oyster River District continues to collaborate and consider information and recommendations from the NH Department of Health and Human Services, the CDC, WHO, and the NH Department of Education each new day.  Your children are, as always, our top priority.  As the current situation regarding the containment of the coronavirus, COVID-19, continues to evolve, we have been able to utilize a number of resources online that we encourage you to read.
\n
\nThere are still many misconceptions regarding COVID-19 that continue to circulate in our school and our community.  Many of you have already taken the time to educate yourselves and your family on this virus, but even then, we encourage you to access these links as information is constantly changing.  Taking a few minutes to view these links may help you understand more about what this virus is, where it has come from, varying symptoms one may have if the virus is contracted, who is being affected, proper hygiene practices, as well as how to help your household plan for continued spread and recommendations to consider if you have travel plans.  We have also included a link from John Hopkins University that explains how this virus is indeed different from Influenza.  The information we share is strictly evidence-based and carries no bias.  While adults are able to educate themselves on these topics, please then also consider using the resources below to help talk to your children as well.  We need to be reminded that we all play a major role in keeping ourselves and those around us safe and healthy the days and weeks ahead.  The talking points provided through KidsHealth.org are incredibly useful.  They include a concise message on how to educate your children on the virus and how to empower them to help stop its spread by properly caring for themselves.  Children CAN make a difference in school, at home, and in our community and we believe it is important that they understand this.
\n
\nImportant to mention is that we have experienced a number of situations where misinformed students and parents that are scared, have created uncomfortable social situations for others who were known to have traveled over our February break or even most recently have known others that have traveled.  Just like bullying, this is not tolerated by our schools and our district and will be dealt with accordingly.  This is another good reason to appropriately educate yourselves and children on COVID-19.  Parents and students alike should never feel criticized for having concern and asking questions!  This IS a concerning situation that requires appropriate attention.
\n
\nWe greatly encourage you to review this information as we will be using this language with your children in the school setting.  Please help us keep children appropriately informed and calm at this time.
\n
\nThank you and again, please feel free to reach out to your school and nursing department with any questions or concerns you may have. 
\n
\nSincerely,
\n
\nYour ORCSD nurses:  Kim Wolph, RN and Kim Langlois, LPN (HS), Erin Pasay, RN, Mike Hope, LPN and Betsy Manchester, Nurse Paraprofessional (MS), Katherine Moore, RN (MW), Sheila Koutelis, RN (MOH), and Lucy Garfield, RN (ORCSD float).
\n
\nBelow is the link to the New Hampshire Dept. of Health and Human Services which provides daily updates on the current situation in our state including positive, negative and pending 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) 
\n
\nBelow is a link from the CDC to important general information about COVID-19.  The CDC follows this situation from a national perspective. 
\n
\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/index.html 
\n
\nBelow is a link from the CDC on how to plan, prepare and respond to COVID-19 as a family.
\n
\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/home/index.html 
\n
\nBelow is a link from the CDC for those who have or plan to travel. 
\n
\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/index.html 
\n
\nBelow is a link to the World Health Organization (WHO) that monitors the COVID-19 situation from a global perspective.
\n
\nhttps://www.who.int
\n
\nBelow is a link for anyone interested in up-to-date research findings on COVID-19 through John Hopkins University’s coronavirus resource center.  Our state epidemiologist has referenced this research.
\n
\nhttps://hub.jhu.edu/2020/03/09/coronavirus-incubation-period/
\n
\nBelow is the link for parents and educators on how to talk with children about COVID-19.  There are many helpful links within this site for adults and parents as well. 
\n
\nhttps://kidshealth.org/en/parents/coronavirus.html?WT.ac=ctg#catbacterial-viral
\n
\nBelow is a link from John Hopkin’s University that explains the difference between COVID-19 and Influenzas. 
\n
\nhttps://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/coronavirus/coronavirus-disease-2019-vs-the-flu
\n
\n***If you are unable to click on these links, please copy and paste into your web browser.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_11","title":"Update #5 3/13/2020","content":"
Dear Parents and Guardians,\n
I am being asked when the ORCSD will be closing school.  Local school systems do not have the authority to close schools for an extended period-of-time.  Superintendents have been in contact with the Governor’s Office and the Commissioner of Education. There are no plans from the state government to close NH schools at this time.\n
The state did pass an emergency measure allowing local school systems to move to remote learning for an extended period of time.\n
We will use Monday, March 16 as a teacher workshop day to build out our rough plan to accommodate remote learning should we choose to do so.  Our goal is to be pro-active, not reactive, to ensure the safety of our students.\n
Please know that the safety of your children is the most important factor as we address uncharted territory.  Additional educational resources and supports will be sent by our school nurses later today via email.\n
Sincerely,\n
Dr. James Morse\n
ORCSD Superintendent","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_12","title":"Update #4 3/13/2020","content":"
Dear Parents and Guardians,\n
We will be moving the Friday, March 20 workshop day to Monday, March 16 in order to do a deep cleaning of all buildings and busses.  We also will be working on our ability to provide remote learning should the state closes schools.\n
Please think about how you would address childcare in the event of a school closure and we move to a remote learning model.  We will continue to keep you informed as the Coronavirus/COVID-19 directives from the state and federal government continue.\n
Another memo will come out later today with more information.\n
Sincerely,\n
Dr. James Morse\n
ORCSD Superintendent","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_13","title":"Update #3 3/4/2020","content":"The news of the Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) has invaded the daily news cycle and of course my inbox.  This memo reflects how we will operate in response to COVID-19 within the Oyster River Cooperative School District.  As of today, there are two confirmed cases in New Hampshire.  We need to consider recommended precautions, reinforce common sense practices, take extraordinary cleaning measures, and address payroll and policy issues now.  The Leadership Team and nurses attended a COVID-19 webinar on Tuesday.  We confirmed current and added new practices outlined in this memo.\nPrecautionary Measures and Preventative Actions to help prevent the spread of COVID-19:\n\n    
Letters and resources sent to the ORCSD staff and community on January 31, 2020 and March 2, 2020.  This information included how the district will respond and react to the COVID-19 based on recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the New Hampshire Division of Public Health Services (NHDPHS).  It also included resource documents for families to review.  We will continue to monitor and communicate with our community.\n    
We have conducted a review of our emergency and operations plans.  We are communicating about essential roles and functions and in discussion regarding our response to potential increased absences.\n    
Encouraging everyday preventative actions:\n    \n        
Frequent washing of hands by staff and students.  This is the number one recommendation from the CDC.  I’ve met with the principals and nurses who will reinforce this practice.  The recommendation is 20 seconds of scrubbing hands equal to two verses of “Happy Birthday” in one’s mind.  Washing hands happens fairly frequently at the elementary level as it is a taught activity, but by middle school and high school we rely on children and adults doing so on their own.  The principals and the nurses at the upper levels will continually remind students and staff of this simple, effective, but common practice.  We also have hand sanitizer available in the schools. \n        
Cover coughs and sneezes with one’s elbow or a tissue.  COVID-19 is now known to transmit person to person.  Coughing or sneezing into one’s elbow contains the direction of the cough or sneeze.  Again, the principals and the nurses will be constantly reminding the staff and students of this simple, yet effective technique. \n        
Reminders for students and staff to stay home if they are sick which always helps to prevent the spread of any illness throughout the schools.  Students and staff should always be fever free for general illnesses for at least 24 hours without taking any fever reducing medication.\n    \n    \n    
The NHDPHS recommends routine and frequent environmental cleaning:\n    \n        
Cleaning common “touch” surfaces over and over and over again.  Jim Rozycki has met with the custodial staff and asked them to double down on cleaning and sanitizing surfaces, doorknobs, bathroom fixtures and other areas commonly touched by staff and students.  This will happen throughout the school day with extensive surface cleaning at night.  Custodians are available throughout the day for additional support, supplies, etc.\n        
Buses will be wiped down before and after runs.  Lisa has already talked to her drivers about the importance of sanitizing the buses frequently based on how enclosed and confined the environment is as well as student to student proximity.\n        
Food Service areas are receiving extra cleaning attention from the school nutrition staff.  Doris has asked the staff to clean common surfaces touched frequently by staff and students, again with approved germ-killing agents.  Due to the nature of kitchens, they have always been scrubbed daily.  This is a continual practice.\n    \n    \n\n
Newly Implemented Practices:\n\n    
We are using CDC and US Department of State Standards as they apply to travel due to COVID-19 to/from foreign countries (these are closely monitored as they can change frequently):\n    \n        
Level 3 alert– CDC recommends that travelers avoid all nonessential travel to the following destinations: China, Iran, Italy, and South Korea (Venezuela is also included due to a general health infrastructure breakdown). The guidance instructs travelers who have visited these countries to “stay home and monitor their health for 14 days after returning to the US”. Countries with a Level 2 alert (Japan) instructs travelers to “monitor their health and to limit their interactions with others for 14 days after returning to the US”.\n        
Level 4 alert – Do not travel: Currently no Level 4 alerts from the CDC based on COVID-19, however no foreign nationals are being permitted into the US from China and Iran at this time.\n        \n            
Asking for parental support by keeping children and their siblings’ home who have been in Level 3 countries.\n            
Providing educational support for students (may include sending work home and/or support once they return to school).\n            
Reviewing and monitoring school sponsored trips (both within the US and Internationally). Preparation has started now, including fact gathering about trip reimbursements and a constant review of travel advisories.\n            
Reviewing non-school sponsored trips and communicating with organizers.\n        \n        \n    \n    \n\n
Sincerely,
\n
\nDr. James C. Morse, Sr.
\nSuperintendent","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_14","title":"Update #2 3/2/2020","content":"
Dear Oyster River Cooperative School District Families and Staff,\n
I want to welcome you back from February vacation and provide an update regarding the health announcement letter sent on January 30th to families and staff. As you know, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is closely monitoring an outbreak of respiratory illness caused by a coronavirus (COVID-19). Currently the CDC and New Hampshire Department of Health and HumanServices has no confirmed cases of the illness in New Hampshire. \n
Our school nurses continue to monitor updates from the CDC, the NH Division of Public Health Services, and the NH Department of Education. The CDC has provided specific recommendations to follow as preventative actions to help prevent the spread of coronavirus such as: wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available, avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands, avoid close contact with people who are sick, stay home when you are sick, cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash, and clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces. As with any illness, if your child is experiencing sickness that includes a fever, cough, respiratory symptoms, nausea, or diarrhea, please keep them out of school. This prevents the spread of any illnesses throughout the schools.\n
Below are the CDC recommendations for those who have traveled (out of the country):\n\n    
Anyone presenting with a mild respiratory illness within 14 days of travel stay home until symptoms resolve, stay away from public places, and if symptoms worsen contact health provider.\n    
Asymptomatic travelers from China, Iran, South Korea, Italy, Venezuela or other countries identified with Level 3 Health Advisories:\n    \n        
Stay home and avoid public places for 14 days\n        
Self-monitor for symptoms\n        
Contact NH DPHS (603-271-4496) or health care provider with symptom-related questions\n    \n    \n    
Asymptomatic travelers from countries identified with COVID-19 community transmission (i.e. those with travel Level 1 or 2 Health Advisories):\n    \n        
Monitor for fever or respiratory symptoms\n        
If symptoms develop, take temperature, and contact healthcare provider or NH DPHS -603-271-4496\n    \n    \n\n
Oyster River Cooperative School District Response\n\n    
Continue to disseminate information to families and staff as available with recommendations from CDC and New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services\n    
Instruct and inform employees, families, and students regarding CDC recommendations\n    
Work with Maintenance and Food Service Departments to maintain sanitation practices\n    
Work with School Nurse staff on additional guidelines and directives as needed\n    
Other recommendations as outlined by Public Health Agencies\n\n
If you have recently traveled abroad or had contact with someone who has traveled abroad, specifically, to countries under a Level 3 Health Advisory, please pay especially close attention to family members with any symptoms that appear flu-like. The recommendation is for you to seek treatment at an Emergency Room (ER), if you are experiencing symptoms of the coronavirus. The <healthcare staff=\"\" at=\"\" the=\"\" er=\"\" will=\"\" be=\"\" equipped=\"\" to=\"\" manage=\"\" your=\"\" care=\"\" and=\"\" further=\"\" treatment.<=\"\" p=\"\">\n\n
The school district continues to monitor the information and recommendations regarding the coronavirus from the CDC and New Hampshire of Department of Health and Human Services. The following resources are helpful and provide updates for families and staff:\n
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: www.cdc.gov 
\nNew Hampshire Department of Health and Human Service : www.dhhs.nh.gov\n
If there are any changes regarding recommendations, the school district will issue an update.\n
Sincerely,\n
 \n
Dr. James C. Morse, Sr.\n
Superintendent","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_15","title":"Update #1 1/31/2020","content":"
Dear Parents and Guardians,
\n
\n\n
\n
As you know, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is closely monitoring an outbreak of respiratory illness caused by a coronavirus first identified in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China. Currently the CDC has no confirmed cases of the illness in New Hampshire.\n
\n
The school district has consulted with the district physician; she is staying in contact with our Director of Student Services regarding any recommendations or updates. Our school nurses at each of our schools are a resource, and are monitoring updates from the CDC, the NH Division of Public Health Services, and the NH Department of Education. The agencies have not provided school-based specific recommendations other than to follow everyday preventative actions to help prevent the spread of respiratory illnesses such as: wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available, avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands, avoid close contact with people who are sick, stay home when you are sick, cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the\n
trash, and clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces. As with any illness, if your child is experiencing sickness that includes a fever, cough, respiratory symptoms, nausea, or diarrhea, please keep them out of school. This prevents the spread of any illnesses throughout the schools.\n
\n
If you have recently traveled abroad or had contact with someone who has traveled abroad, specifically to and from China, please pay especially close attention to family members with any symptoms that appear flu-like. The recommendation is for you to seek treatment at an Emergency Room (ER), if you are experiencing symptoms of the coronavirus. The healthcare staff at the ER will be equipped to manage your care and further treatment.\n
\n
There are no recommendations to keep your healthy child home due to this outbreak. If there are any changes regarding recommendations, the school district will issue an update. Communication with the school nurses is welcomed. If you have questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to reach out to:\n
\n
Katherine Moore, School Nurse at Mast Way: kmoore@orcsd.org
\nSheila Koutelis, School Nurse at Moharimet: skoutelis@moharimet
\nErin Pasay, School Nurse at Oyster River Middle School: epasay@orcsd.org
\nKimberly Wolph, School Nurse at Oyster River High School: kwolph@orcsd.org
\nLucy Garfield, Floater School Nurse: lgarfield@orcsd.org\n
\n
Sincerely,
\n
\n\n
\n
Dr. James C. Morse, Sr.
\nSuperintendent\n

                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
